note.p: Boyle Heights is a product of socio-economic, political, and ethnic discrimination and a site of resistance and cultural wealth.

listBibl.bibl: Diaz, David R. Barrio Urbanism: Chicanos, Planning, and American Cities. New York: Routledge, 2005. Print. ...
Sanchez, George J. “What's Good for Boyle Heights Is Good for the Jews": Creating Multiracialism on the Eastside during the 1950s.” American Quarterly 56.3 (2004): 633–661. Print. ...

“Boyle Heights.” Mapping L.A. n.p., n.d. Web. 8 Feb. 2016.
...

div.p: Boyle Heights is a product of race-based exclusionary practices in city planning and urban policy coupled with the actions of local officials and the federal government to economically, politically, and socially repress the multiracial community that once characterized this East Los Angeles neighborhood in the early twentieth century. Today Boyle Heights is home to a predominantly Mexican-American working class, but it was not always this way. Before becoming more ethnically homogenous, Boyle Heights was a haven for diverse ethnic groups such as the Jewish, Mexicans, Japanese, Italians, Armenians, African Americans, and Russian Molokans; all of whom learned to coexist by their common experiences of exclusion from the developing middle-class American-born Anglo communities on the west side. However, by way of multiracial organizing and advocacy toward social and racial justice, the Boyle Heights community was able to combat some of the obstacles they faced. Today, it remains a site of resistance.

note.p: Boyle Heights is a product of socio-economic, political, and ethnic discrimination and a site of resistance and cultural wealth.

listBibl.bibl: Diaz, David R. Barrio Urbanism: Chicanos, Planning, and American Cities. New York: Routledge, 2005. Print.
Sanchez, George J. “What's Good for Boyle Heights Is Good for the Jews": Creating Multiracialism on the Eastside during the 1950s.” American Quarterly 56.3 (2004): 633–661. Print.
